snp2.12:0.1_0: Book, the arrow springs from the underworld.
snp2.12:1.10_0: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and addressed the Buddha in verse:
snp2.12:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine.
snp2.12:1.3_0: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa was the chief named Nigrodhakappa, Venerable Nigrodhakappa, Venerable Purāṇa, when he became fully extinguished.
snp2.12:1.4_0: Then, while he was in seclusion, he thought,
snp2.12:1.5_0: Is extinguished upon myself, or not?
snp2.12:1.6_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Vaṅgīsa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
snp2.12:1.7_0: and told him what had happened.
snp2.12:1.9_0: Is extinguished before his preceptor has become fully extinguished?
snp2.12:10.1_0: You have entirely abandoned birth and death;
snp2.12:10.2_0: restrained and pure, speak the Dhamma!
snp2.12:10.3_0: Ordinary people can’t fulfill all their wishes,
snp2.12:10.4_0: but the Realized Ones can achieve what they wish.
snp2.12:11.1_0: Your answer is definitive, and we will accept it,
snp2.12:11.3_0: We raise our joined palms one last time,
snp2.12:11.4_0: your wisdom is unrivaled, so do not knowingly confuse us.
snp2.12:12.1_0: Knowing the teaching of the noble ones from top to bottom,
snp2.12:12.2_0: your energy is unrivaled, so do not knowingly confuse us.
snp2.12:12.3_0: Like a man in the baking summer sun would long for water,
snp2.12:12.4_0: I long for the rain of your voice to fall on my ears.
snp2.12:13.1_0: Surely Kappāyana did not lead the spiritual life in vain?
snp2.12:13.3_0: or did he still have a remnant of defilement?
snp2.12:13.4_0: Let us hear what kind of liberation he had!”
snp2.12:14.1_0: “He cut off craving for mind and body in this very life,”
snp2.12:14.3_0: “The river of darkness that had long lain within him.
snp2.12:14.4_0: He has entirely crossed over birth and death.”
snp2.12:14.5_0: So declared the Blessed One, the leader of the five.
snp2.12:15.1_0: “Now that I have heard your words,
snp2.12:15.2_0: seventh of sages, I am confident.
snp2.12:15.3_0: My progressive teaching was in vain:
snp2.12:16.1_0: As he spoke, so he acted;
snp2.12:16.2_0: he was a disciple of the Buddha.
snp2.12:16.3_0: He cut the net of death the deceiver,
snp2.12:17.3_0: He has indeed gone far beyond
snp2.12:17.4_0: Death’s domain so hard to pass.”
snp2.12:2.1_0: “I ask the teacher unrivaled in wisdom,
snp2.12:2.2_0: who has cut off all doubts in this very life—
snp2.12:3.2_0: it was given to that brahmin by you, Blessed One.
snp2.12:3.3_0: He wandered in your honor, yearning for freedom,
snp2.12:3.4_0: energetic, a resolute Seer of Truth.
snp2.12:4.1_0: I also want my own disciple,
snp2.12:4.2_0: all of us wish to know about that disciple.
snp2.12:4.3_0: Our ears are eager to hear,
snp2.12:4.4_0: for you are truly the most excellent teacher.
snp2.12:5.1_0: Cut off our doubt, declare this to us;
snp2.12:5.2_0: your wisdom is vast, tell us of his quenching!
snp2.12:5.4_0: like the thousand-eyed Sakka in the midst of the gods!
snp2.12:6.1_0: Whatever ties there are, or paths to delusion,
snp2.12:6.2_0: or things on the side of unknowing, or that are bases of doubt
snp2.12:6.3_0: They don’t understand the Realized One,
snp2.12:6.4_0: for his eye is the best of all people’s.
snp2.12:7.1_0: For if no man were ever to disperse corruptions,
snp2.12:7.2_0: like the wind dispersing a mass of clouds,
snp2.12:7.4_0: not even brilliant men would shine.
snp2.12:8.1_0: The wise are makers of light;
snp2.12:8.2_0: my hero, that is what I think of you.
snp2.12:8.3_0: We’ve come to you for your discernment and knowledge:
snp2.12:8.4_0: here in this assembly, declare to us about Kappāyana.
snp2.12:9.1_0: Swiftly send forth your graceful voice,
snp2.12:9.2_0: like a goose stretching its neck, gently honking,
snp2.12:9.3_0: smooth in sound, with a lovely tone:
snp2.12:9.4_0: alert, we are all listening to you.
